name: WILD BLUE FLAX
description: stigma capitate (headed); plant produces many branches from the base; styles of same length on different plants.

name: MOUSE-EAR CHICKWEED
description: floral stems with tufts of sterile shoots in leaf axils (angle where leaves join stems); bracts (small leaf-like structures) of the inflorescence (flower cluster) with scarious (dry, thin, papery) margins.
habitat: meadows and openings in pine forests.

name: COMMON FIREWEED
description: raceme (flower cluster with stalked flowers along a main axis) not leafy; styles hairy at the base, exceeding the stamens.

name: TINY TRUMPET
description: leaves lanceolate (lance-shaped); flowers in a dense terminal cluster surrounded by enlarged, leaf-like bracts (small leaf-like structures).

name: TWINBERRY
description: flowers seated in conspicuous, leaflike cup of bracts (small leaf-like structures).
habitat: along mountain streams and moist slopes at 6,000 to 10,000 feet.

name: SULPHUR FLOWER
description: grows in broad, loose mats; perianth (petals and sepals) narrowed at the base to a stipe (stalk) and externally glabrous (smooth).
habitat: forest openings, dry meadows, rocky slopes at 5,000 to 11,500 feet.

name: BEDSTRAW
description: leaves lanceolate (lance-shaped), blunt-tipped, 4 at a node (point on a stem where leaves or branches occur); inflorescence (flower cluster) pyramidal.

name: RICHARDSON GERANIUM
description: petals white with purple veins, pilose (having long, soft hairs) on the lower half; plant erect with a single or a few stems.
habitat: moist, shaded areas; aspen groves, spruce-fir forests.

name: FAIRY TRUMPET
common_name: skyrocket, scarlet gilia (red form), white gilia
description: ovary with 3 locules (compartments); corolla (petals) salverform (with a long narrow tube opening into a wider cup i.e. trumpet-shaped).

name: BUTTER AND EGGS
description: leaves glabrous (smooth, hairless) and glaucous (contains white waxy covering).

name: SILVERY LUPINE
description: tip of keel (lower petal in pea family) long and slender, erect or slanting forward; leaves are palmately compound (divided like a hand); leaflets often conduplicate (folded lengthwise).

name: WILD LILY-OF-THE-VALLEY
common_name: star solomon's seal; star solomon's plume, few-flowered false solomon seal
description: flowers in a raceme (stalked flowers along a main axis).
habitat: shady, moist areas in the forested mountains.

name: SILVERY POTENTILLA
description: leaves pinnate with toothed leaflets, silvery-pubescent, often bi-colored; flowers 0.5 inch diameter; stems tufted.
habitat: dry hillsides, gravelly slopes, trailsides, forest edges.

name: PASQUE FLOWER
description: tepals (undifferentiated petals and sepals) overlapping; upper stem leaves form a whorl below the flower; leaves and stems pubescent (hairy).
habitat: open forests at 8,500 to 11,500 feet elevation.

name: WOODS ROSE
description: leaflets 5 - 7; flowering stems with broad-based thorns, occasional bristles; sepals 2 mm wide at base.
habitat: valleys, gulches, trailsides at 6,000 to 11,000 feet elevation.

name: FENDLER MEADOWRUE
description: flowers mostly unisexual (either male or female); anthers much longer than wide; upper and lower edges of fruits mostly convex.
habitat: meadows, aspen groves from 5,000 to 9,500 feet elevation.
